I've never expected so many twists and turns in this movie's plot, let alone all the backstabbing each character performs upon each other!! No one can trust each other-- it is truly amazing!

The acting is fantastic in this movie. BUT even more amazing is the elaborate set design, phenomenal costuming, make-up, and spectacular cinematography throughout this movie. The only thing that wasn't great about this movie was the plot, which could have been a bit more improved and less soap opera-esque!

It's a stunning visual achievement. Robes, architecture, landscape - it's all vibrant and dramatic. Everything indoors is gold or brilliant color. Ritual, costume, jewelry, even golden makeup all contribute to color that almost screams off the screen. Then, towards the end, the sheer mass of humanity involved (even if CGI) made the "cast of thousands" cliche seem paltry. China has had many things in its history, but first has always been the overwhelming numbers of its populace. For all that, this isn't a movie about its appearance.

It's about revenge, intrigue, honor, and the appearance of honor - sometimes the opposite of honor itself. Year after year, layer after layer of subterfuge accretes, until every loyalty and most disloyaties are torn in multiple directions. It's not just Macchiavellian - old Niccolo wouldn't have lasted until lunch.

The fights, and there are many, mostly lack the setpiece choreography that could have made them memorable. The physical combat is the least of it. Hatred to hatred, face to face, this describes a fight between the characters' inner filth, served up in a golden dish.

-- wiredweird

'curse of the golden flower' is a movie i anxiously waited to see.  after the great 'hero,' and excellent 'house of flying daggers,' i was very excited to at the prospect of a new zhang yimou film.

a lot of the criticism aimed of 'curse' isn't unfounded. the plot is barely there, but 'curse' is more a study of family dynamics, loyalty, betrayal, dishonesty, hidden secrets, quasi-incestuous relationships, maternal love and paternal hatred than a grand and epic film.  most of the scenes are confined to the empress' quarters and surrounding palace. only one sequence that i can remember takes place outside the palace--and it's a great sequence (and the only one which really showcases the trademark wuxia acrobatics).

chow yun-fat and gong li are both excellent in their roles of emperor and empress. chow yun-fat is almost frigtening in his cruelty (and i have to say that his salt-n-pepper goatee really works for him. he's an incredibly handsome man--which makes the emperor's cruelty all the more effective) and the ever-lovely gong li is terrific as the slowly-going-mad empress.  since it is more a character study, the burden of making the film watchable falls squarely on the the leads and they rise to the occassion, particularly gong li.  she does a nice job of evoking the viewer's empathy.

zhang yimou is peerless when it comes to visual artisty. i suspect he blows 1/2 his budget on scenery. he crams so much into each you practically need to hit pause every 10 seconds just to take a look at the feasts that are his backgrounds.  as the title suggests, yellow is the color of choice in this film, and he always uses it effectively, even though it sometimes comes close to overwhelming the film.

if there's a problem with 'curse,' it's that does drift a bit into the melodramatic, particularly as all the secrets are 'revealed' and each character's motivations become clear. since it is a tragedy, few people make it to the film's ending, and those deaths are bloody and, for the most part, graphic--particularly the emperor's flogging of his own son. which leads me to believe that the moral of 'curse of the golden flower' is this: don't, under any circumstance, mess with chow yun-fat. he'll knock you into the next decade and not lose a blink of sleep over it. i also found the ending a bit problematic and too vague. it's not that i need all the answers or a tidy bow around it, but the denoument is perplexing at best; and not to mention the score, which at a moment of supreme tragedy, sounds like the ending to an animated disney film. the music is fine on its own, but seems very inappropriate and distracts from the emotional bloodletting you've just experienced.

in short, i enjoyed 'the curse of the golden flower,' but if you're not already a fan of zhang yimou and/or chinese cinema, you could probably just skip this one and go back to 'hero' or 'house of flying daggers.'

(about the R rating -- it seems a bit on the severe side.  sure, it's bloody and violent during the last 40 minutes, but no more so than the average episode of '24,' so if you can handle that, you can handle this).

Like most reviewers, I agree that this is a visually stunning movie. The plot is heavy on the Shakespeare and as such it leaves much up to the viewer to seek answers to the questions that arise. The acting is well done throughout, especially Gong Li and Jay Chou who portrays the natural son of Gong Li's Phoenix character. According to the special features he is a newcomer to the screen, having made his mark as a pop star. I'm impressed, especially given the high rate of failure in such a career move. Chow Yun-Fat is good but was a bit over-the-top to me, flaring his nostrils and popping his eyes to convey emotion. Still, there is a scene late in the movie that was as hard to watch as I'm sure it was hard to act. You'll know it when you see it and it shows much more accurately why he (along with Gong Li) are such widely acclaimed cinematic actors.
The movie packs a lot in, from the excessively opulent sets and eye candy to the Greek tragedy levels of bloodshed that come at the climax of the film. When it's all said and done, however, I felt a bit letdown at the lack of substance that I took away from the film. The action sequences leaned heavily on huge battles scenes rife with CGI trickery instead of one-on-one duals. Yes, both are jaw-dropping, but I simply prefer the latter. This movie might be your cup of tea and there is much to enjoy from a purely sensory level, but it wasn't as emotionally gratifying as I'd hoped.
So very pretty, such a let down. Hero and House of Flying Daggers were both so incredible that it was hard to believe it was from the same director.

Don't misunderstand the title of my review above, as it's not necessarily a bad thing. I rarely write reviews, but having read many of the bad reviews here concerning badly scripted dialogues/actions and confusing plot, I simply must add my 2 cents. This is typical of chinese movies. They don't lay everything out for you from beginning to end. You have to actually THINK in order to fully understand the whole thing. And traditionally, chinese people do speak that way. They don't just say it outright, they tend to use metaphors and such to word their intent. Why?!?! I don't know. They just do. So before you start criticizing the way the characters speak or the way the plot unfolds, you should do a little research beforehand (or just stick to cheesy b-movies).

This is a great movie. Normally, I am not into these types of film but I am glad I watched it.  The film is breathtakingly beautiful, in terms of colors and camera works (same director that made "Hero".  This is much better than Hero by far).  It is so good that after I watched it on regular DVD, loaned from a friend, I went on Amazon and ordered the blu-ray version.

Gong Li and CYF are the pros at story telling.  The movie is very grand and MUST be seen in Chinese audio and English subtitle to get the true feelings from the real actors voices.  Although if you opt for English dub, it is very good too.

I am sure this blu-ray version will be fantastic. Will write up how it looks once I get a chance to view it.

I saw this film in the theater and am now it buying on DVD, which I do very infrequently.  I am doing so for two reasons.  Firstly, this is among the most visually stunning films I have ever seen and I frequently have flashbacks of different scenes, ablaze with vivid colors and striking images.  Secondly, this among the most absorbing stories I can recall.  I read a lot of Shakespeare when I was younger and I certainly recognized a lot of elements from the Bard's stories.  That being said, I think the film deals with universal themes that are undoubtedly explored in the Eastern literary tradition as well: honor, family values, allegiance and sexuality among them.  This is a timeless film with timeless themes and I imagine would speak to any thoughtful person, from any culture.  5 stars.

Without any doubt this is one of the most brilliantly compelling movies ever made. The cimetography is mind-boggling spectacular. The dazzling colors,costumes,acting,plot,etc.etc.etc. all contribute to an extraodinary cinematic experience. I've read a lot of negative comments on the plot being shallow,confusing etc.  I find this utterly preposterous. The plot is brilliantly concieved and leaves you unsure and guessing until the end. The action scenes(while over the top as is typical of Chinese films)are some of the best ever filmed. This film is graced by some of the greatest actors in the world today(Gong Li, Yun-Fat Chow)and their performances are genius. Curse of the Golden Flower is a masterpiece and is worthy of being considered one of the greatest films of all time.

A definite must see if you enjoyed Hero. It's like an asian soap opera but how meticulous with respect they are in this movie is unrivaled. Chow-Yun Fat of course maintains his top-dog style in the movie.

Pluses: it's a bodice-ripper, it's got great colour, and it's got Chow Yun-Fat chewing the scenery.  Minuses: it's not got much of a plot to speak of, and everything is so inevitable.  A rental, rather than a purchase, is my recommendation.

I can't give it a five thats for sure.  I think the actors chosen for this movie were PERFERCT! Yun Fat Chow delivered his normal impecable performance, I had never seen Gong Li before but I could tell she's one of the best...SHE is the reason I watched this movie through to the end. I liked all of the color and scenery, and I'm glad there wasn't too much martial arts because that turns me off.

What brought this movie down for me was the plot.  This plot was soooo intricate that it didn't even make sense.  It's like it was wound so much that they thought they'd confuse us but they didn't.  Throughout the movie you're constantly asking yourself, "why is this happening?", "why is he doing that?", "what caused this?" or "how?".  How could so much be going on under one roof and only a few people know? I don't want to spoil the plot as someone else has (lol), but the plot was kind of spoiled already. (hehe)

What you find while watching this movie is you're seeing what happens after years of lies and deciet have taken over, but you are NEVER told what led up to these few days.  Even in the end you're left wondering what happened next because it just fades to black.  The ending was kind of dumb now that I think of it.

This was a pretty good movie all in all.  I don't regret buying it because I will watch it again, but it's not at all 5 star material.

Despite actors and directors that have delivered before, this is a complete waste of time viewing.  I hear the film is being referred to on the mainland as The Curse of the Golden Cleavage. Quite a disappointment to say the least.

`Curse of the Flower' is a gorgeous masterpiece.  Filled with the uniform pageantry of The Tang Dynasty (A.D. 928), the layers of beauty are unfolded to reveal the household of the Emperor (Yun Fat) whose dramatic crisis is intimately revealed amidst the busy hive of his kingdom.  Treason, incest, and treachery against kin are concretely provided for a drama of Shakespearean proportions.  The queen (Empress) of the hive is ailing with what the Emperor believes to be anemia.  After ten years of ancient herbal medicine, she is no means closer to a cure.  More hemorrhaging is the rivalry amongst the two sons who spar for succession like Cain and Abel.  Jai (Jay Chou), the elder, appears like the humble, reluctant successor; while his bitter young rival, Wan (Liu Ye) has a sword to grind with his past and a manipulative lover who has no little influence over him.  The poor Emperor, revealed with no clothes, is wise to the point of tempering his judgment amongst poisonous ingratitude.  Heavy wears the crown for a man who resiliently defies the Shakespearean line, "Death hath murdered sleep."  Suspenseful, the plot lines head for a climax during the Chrysanthemum Festival for which the Empress intricately prepares.

Stylish on every score, 'Curse of the Flower' could have been an overwrought melodrama with not enough substance, but story and dcor only bring out the best of one another.  Never did I feel like this offering was tainted by trivialities.  I neglected this cinematic offering on the suspicion I was going to get an ancient and foreign offering of 'Kill Bill, No. 1' with tiresome martial arts scenes.  Judiciously, the dramatic and combat scenes are gorgeously choreographed and timed to meticulous precision without draining the attention span of the audience.  The battle scenes are innovative in a way reminiscent of , 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon' except with more stunning results.  If nothing else, it contrasts new horizons of technical achievement that make 'Matrix' borrowing seem stale.

Intense but expert acting and meticulous craftsmanship combine to make a magnificent epic adventure.  'Curse of the Golden Flower' is a singular achievement for director Yimou Zhang and all involved who assembled an excellent Eastern tragedy.

The last Asian, or in this case, Chinese movies have stunned the world with their unorthodox, but typically Asian style that has never entered a competition with Hollywood - because Hollywood cannot compete with such things. I think it is even inappropriate to compare Hollywood to "Beijingwood". The Chinese rely much on the visual aspects of a movie, not much like Kubrick used to do, they rather choose an epic and immensely beautiful way, then they mix it with superb martial arts (which the Asians were and still are popular for) and add incredibly touching, Asian music which completes the masterpiece.

I do not speak like this because I'm Asian or I am a huge fan of Asian stuff only - no, I simply like movies of all kinds and like to compare them, see what is better or worse, what is new and what is just cliche. After seing Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Hero and The House of Flying Daggers I was struck by the cinematic wave from China - the movies are just extraordinary, not only in visual and fighting aspects, but also in all other ones like narration of the story, camera work, usage of music and editing and so on and forth. The movies are just something special, but it also can be understood in a different way, so there are plenty of people who do not like this kind of film - agreed, a Hollywood freak will never like such non-mainstream stuff and will rather watch a run-of-the-mill movie like Rocky Balboa where you know what is happening in the next minutes and how it ends even when you watch it the first time.

So, in my opinion (and I think many people will agree), the Asian film of the last decade, maybe excepting the martial-arts-only films like Ong Bak (which are fine, too, but for another reasons), has grown on the movie industry and will not back off that easily. The Curse of the Golden Flower, the third popular movie by Zhang Yimou, combines a very complex story, halfway stolen from and based on Shakespeare's King Lear and other drama, with IMMENSELY beautiful pictures that somewhat may feel like an LSD trip, but in a good way, strong acoustic composition and very fine acting - all four aspects that an average Hollywood movie does not fulfill. As told in the 20-minute-making Of, everyone of us hides something inside, and so does the incredibly great imperial family of the Chinese emperor. Who has ever read King Lear or Hamlet, will see many parallels. The plot is very interesting, but also pretty difficult to follow, in the almost 110 minutes the story unfolds the terrible secrets that hide within every member of the family. Not to make the audience get tired by following the complex paths and threads, the movie uses visual effects that blast everything of that the film industry has ever shown - the movie without sound is a delight itself.

Of course, there are some martial art scenes, but they are not the quintessence of the film, in this case it is really more the story. Near the end, there is a really, really really FANTASTIC battle with more that 1000 real-person extras (not like in Lord of the Rings, 10 extras multiplied by computer effects!). It is just worth buying the movie to see the beautiful mass scenes that will steal your breath. Filmed on the probably biggest open set the world has seen, the crew had huge possibilities to show the dimensions of the palace and the battles, and it worked greatly, especially because you will see the difference between a real set and a computer animated set like in the aforementioned LotR. The acting itself is not the strength of the movie, as except for Gong Li and Chow Yun-Fat, who played extraordinarily well, the actors were not much of professionals, but they did their job very, very well, too.

Watching the movie in English irritates a little, because it is hard to synchronize a I-don't-open-my-mouth-much-when-I-speak language like Chinese, but the audio is still pretty good, although not always. The subtitles are useless, they are more free style than connected to the spoken lines. The specials of the DVD are little, but nice, worth watching anyway.

I highly recommend to buying this film for all, who like the Asian style movies - but also for people, who like watching theatre, or movies with complex stories that do have action, but do not build up on it. Indeed, it would be hard to watch without the beautiful visual work the Chinese have done again, and the movie business should thank them. Gigantic non-mainstream masterpiece with visual fireworks that will stay in your mind for a long time. Cursed with great taste.

Do not buy if you do not like to think much when watching a film, this is not a movie to be followed easily, it will not let you relax.

Curse of the Golden Flower gold and jade on the outside, rot and decay on the inside.  Curse of the Golden Flower is a movie about the ultimate dysfunctional royal family, during the Chinese Tang Dynasty.

This is a good Chinese movie, which becomes more understandable, if you read subtitles, and listen to the Mandarin Chinese language track.  If you listen to the dubbed English language track, then the plot need some explaining.  You must be able to connect the dots, if you listen to the dubbed English, the movie requires some and extrapolating because of a bad editing job.

However, if you like action, drama, and terrific cinematography, then you should like this movie.  This movie could also be called The Curse of the Golden Corset.

One of the best filmed movies I have seen.  The visuals are what movies are supposed to look like.  And the story is just clasical, a tale of love, hate, corruption and jealousy, that grips at the very fabric of human emotion.

As most of the reviewers agree, this movie is so impressive visually.  The coloring of the costumes, buildings, backgrounds, and scenery are amazing. (Especially in HDTV !)

I enjoyed the plot and the manipulation of the royal family.  However, if you watch action films, you know what is coming in the movie.

The movie rolls slowly, but it is interesting to watch as the Emperor and Empress plot against each other, though you see more of the inner workings of the Empress.

I definitely was expecting more martial arts in the film for some reason, but that did not happen all that much.  Though the few scenes were cool, it did not have the consistency of "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" or " House of Flying Daggers".  Chow Yun Fat is fine in the film, but I wish he had more screen time.  He is definitely one of my favorite Asian actors.  His arrogance as the Emperor at times were amusing at times, especially when he was stroking his chin whiskers.

All in all, it was an entertaining, visually stimulating film, but again if you are looking for an action-packed Martial Arts film, then go buy Hero or Crouching Tiger !

This is one of the most beautiful movies you are ever going to watch.  Must be seen on a big screen.  You'll find yourself asking in the middle of the movie, is that real - how did they do that - and just wow.  The special features has a documentary that shows,indeed, most of what you see is real.  They could only make this in China.

The problem is the plot gives you lots of time to ask how did they do that as their isn't more action.  This really is a soap opera and not in the same genre of Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon.  I wanted more action and more fighting but I am a guy.

Beautiful visuals.  Interesting story.  As usual, you don't know who's the "bad guy" and who's the "good guy" until the end - and even then it's a surprise and not as clear cut as it seems.  If you liked Hero, you will probably like this movie as well.

Note that this movie does contain some adult themes (no real nudity, but some references to incest).

The Curse of the Golden Flower stars great Chinese actors Gong Li and Chow Yun-Fat.  Psychedelic in its opulence, the setting of the Forbidden City during the Tang Dynasty (900 A.D.) and the costumes of the cast of thousands, are as decadent as eating wedding cake for a week.

Yet the plot is as thin as an Oriental screen.  Not intending to be a spoiler, like most modern Chinese movies, e.g. Raise the Red Lantern, also starring Li, the ending of "Flower" is depressing, everyone dies, and evil prevails.

Set during the Chrysanthemum Festival, held the ninth day of the ninth month of every year, the emperor, empress, princes, and various courtiers poison each other and plot coups.

I used to have great respect for its director Zhang until he started to make big budget martial arts fantasy films. I am sorry to say this film is a superficial skin deep junk. Visually it is stunning but its story line is completely senseless. It is as if the plot is an after thought for the sake of the visual effects Zhang envisions. It claims to be in the Tang dynasty but the only thing which might has something to do with the era is the low-cut women dresses. Yet even that is way overdone. What a disgrace!

Every single character in this movie is flawed, from the evil emperor to the youngest son.  Each character is filled with subtle nuances and rich with emotion.  The actors play their parts with a brilliant talent.  These actors shine.  Gong Li and Chow Yun Fat don't get any better.

As for the story itself, although you expect some what happens, the ending still manages the unexpected.  This is the tale of betrayel of the worst sort, an evil Emperor to rival Emperors, love gone wrong, and murder most foul.

Then there's the set design.  This is one of the most beautiful sets, as well as gorgeous art direction since House of Flying Daggers.  The costumes are lush and beautiful as well.  I will say one thing though, the women's costumes, while flashy, aren't very historical.

This movie like other's from Yimou Zhang is agonizingly beautiful.

A masterpiece and a bridge between martial arts and Zhang Yimou's classic arthouse movies

First I have to tell you that I'm a great fan of the well known chinese director Zhang Yimou. His "Raise The Red Lantern" is one of my fovorites. As well I am familiar with his martial artworks like "Hero" and "House Of  Flying Daggers". This stunning movie shows Zhang Yimous whole repertoir and is a great combination of both styles. The first half is a festival for your eyes in style of red lantern but much better, bigger and more visual. The second half will make beat the heart of every martial arts fan faster. Depending on your obsessions and interests you probably will like only one half of that movie - eighter the first if you are interested in character deepness and stunning pictures, or the second if you like to see phantastic never before seen fighting scenes (never let your kids see the second half). Both halfs are a great masterpiece within it's genre and worth the money if you prefer one gernre only. The skip chapter function on a DVD makes it possible to select your prefered part - it alone will be the money for the whole DVD worth. My wish is that this combination works as intended: to get martial arts fans invited to real movie rarities and let them buy "Raise The Red Lantern" after seeng this and open an eye for arthouse frieds to movies like "Hero".

At the end I have to tell, that you don't have to learn chinese before watching this DVD - it comes with english audio and subtitles as well.

... A visual feast that will leave you starving for a plot. Yikes! What a disappointment this movie was.  Visually, it is undeniably beautiful to take in, but unfortunately, it's just not enough to keep you interested. The dysfunction in this family is monumental. The emperor is poisoning his wife, but why?  By his own admission, he knew of her incestuous affair prior to poisoning her.  Why didn't he start poisoning her from the get go? He kills off his first wife (were they ever really married?) and her family but there isn't a plausible explanation as to why. Supposedly, because of his lust for power, he convinces Gong Li's father (a king no less) to give him her hand in marriage, but how?  He was a lowly captain. Why would a KING marry off his daughter to a captain.  How did he become emperor?  We find out later that his first wife did in fact survive and went on to marry the imperial doctor who showed kindness to her, unbeknownst to the emperor. How is that the emperor didn't know his own private physician's wife? It makes no sense.

In the end, all the unaswered questions were too distracting. I really wish I had rented this BEFORE I bought the DVD.

"The curse of the golden flower" represents the origin and the end of  a dynasty, a nasty cycle that finds in the tragedy the final solution, the natural destiny of a set of incidents, facts and those unsaid little sins, that sharp and establish in that decaying real family, the obvious consequence of an ethical deficit: incest, vengeance, adultery, greed, double cross, hypocrisy and murder in slow motion.

The Empress has a mission: to prepare surreptitiously a complex plan, that should lead the Emperor to abdicate through a merciless process when she realizes the Emperor intends by all his means to eliminate her.

Yhimou Zang `s prestige as filmmaker is far to be a secret. Owner of an enviable talent, he directs this admirable masterpiece with impeccable accuracy, taking into account the most minimum details. Cinematography, camerawork, edition, traveling and that absolute domain of the "cinematographic time" that reminds us traces and signals of the epic Akira Kurosawa in the final sequences, the admirable fights, the repressed feelings and the dramatic climax. Make of this film not only one of the best ten films of the year. It's besides, an absolute and instantaneous classic.

Curse of the Golden Flower proves to be a rather complex movie that belied and perhaps fooled some of the previous reviewers. This is one film that almost requires a repeat viewing due to many twists and turns of the story. Its a movie about a corrupt imperial family doing their utmost to backstabbed each other. There is really no "good guys" in this movie. If the son was dutiful to his mother, he was a traitor to his father. If the wife was being poisoned by her husband, she also committed incestous acts with her own stepson. Just one totally dyfunctional family heading toward ruins. But due to the complex nature of the plot, Chinese language with English subtitles as well as some poor editing done for the American released, this movie need to be seen twice before everything fall into place.

Chow Yun-Fat and Gong Li are two of the most recongizable Chinese actors out there and they both gave a strong performance that complemented each other. They were well supported by their supporting cast and production values of this movie proves to be strong. Directed by Ghang Yimou who did Hero and House of the Flying Daggers, the usages of colors and costumes in this movie make it visual feast for the eyes.

I found the movie to be interesting and entertaining. The major weakness of this movie appears to be that its over edited. It pretty clear that the American version cut out few scenes here and there. The running time of 114 minutes appears to be too short. The only feature that come with this DVD, the making of this movie, it pretty clear that some parts of this movie have been cut for reasons unknown. But that does make the movie flow more jerky-like then smooth. It also short changed the story and the script, perhaps thinking that American audience may not have the patience to sit through a good story before the action.

The DVD of this movie proves to be in an excellent shape. The images and colors proves to be vivid and shape. The 5.1 DD is pretty aggressive and clear. The only major featuratte of this DVD is the "Making of" feature that proves to be mildly interesting.

Overall, a pretty spectacular film with a real meat of a story that got short changed by poor editing. Maybe someday, we will get to see the whole thing but until then, this movie come well recommendation to buy instead of rent since if you haven't seen it already in the theater, it worth watching it twice to get the whole gust of this whirlwind story.

Zhang Yimou directed this wonderful epic.  His "Raise the Red Lantern" was nominated for a Best Foreign Language film Oscar in 1991 as was "Hero" in 2002.  "Curse of the Yellow Flower" does not have the swashbuckling pyrotechnics of "House of Flying Daggers," but it does have a domestic intimacy surrounded by the grandeur of the Chinese royal court.  Chow Yun-Fat from "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" plays the ruthless emperor who kills his youngest son to protect his throne.  We watched the racing DVD "Initial D" with Chinese pop singer Jay Chou recently.  It is a real shift to watch him almost back-to-back with this film where he goes from heartbroken teen race car driver to martial arts prince in a period film.  What a stretch!  As Prince Jai who sides with the Empress, he does a great job of leading hordes of golden-uniformed soldiers into battle.  The battle sequences with the various armies color coded in gold, blue, red or silver is visually stunning.  Gong Li is one of the world's most accomplished actresses.  From "Zhou Yu's Train" to "The Story of Qui Ju" for which she won the Volpi Cup for Best Actress at the 1992 Venice Film Festival to "Memoirs of Geisha" for which she won Best Supporting Actress from the National Board of Review, she plays an array of characters.  As the Empress, her performance is subtle, nuanced and varied as she experiences madness and then the bitterness of discovery that she is being poisoned.  The odd note for the character is her love affair with her stepson, which seems a bit unusual by today's Western standards.  Liu Ye played the violinist Ma in his first film "Balzac & the Little Chinese Seamstress."  Here, as the middle son and crown prince, he plays a character not sure of himself & not desirous of power.  It proves a lethal dose as he tries to commit suicide before being run through by his younger sibling, Prince Yu played by Qin Junjie in his first film.  The supporting players are all fabulous including Ni Dahong as the doctor & Li Man as his daughter Chan.  While I didn't get her name, the woman who plays the doctor's wife turns in a superb performance.  The costume design is exquisite as reflected in the film's lone Oscar nomination for Yee Chung-man's Best Costumes.  Zhou Xiaoding's cinematography is also exquisite as reflected by awards from both the Boston & New York Film Critics Societies.  American films today rarely have a sense of classical tragedy such as Yimon's films can reflect.  Gong Li is worth the price of admission, but there is so much more.  Enjoy!

The hardest thing to do with this film is explaining exactly what it's about. You have an emperor (Chow Yun-Fat) who has been away taking care of business but is now returning home for the chrysanthemum festival. You have an Empress who has been waiting for him to return home for even longer than he's been gone. His wife grew lonely and turned to her stepson for love among other things. Then there's her maternal sons, Prince Jai will be a great emperor and will stand by her side to the end. Prince Yu gets little love from either of his parents but he knows the little secret between his stepbrother and mother. There is so much that happens in the film that I can't tell anymore but most likely you'll put it together before it ends.

With so much going on and so many characters there is truly little room for character development. So many other elements cover for the lack of character development that I stopped caring about it by the middle of the movie. One major example is the story, which was predictable but was written so well that I still enjoyed how it was pieced and how it unfolded. As seen in the previews it's obvious that this movie has beautiful settings, maybe the most beautiful and colorful I've ever seen. I'm not the type to really pay attention to costumes but the costumes in this movie were out of this world. The settings and costumes are what you notice first when the film opens.

There aren't too many action scenes and this may actually get to some people but the story makes up for that too. The acting was all around great especially the newcomers. Chow Yun-Fat was great and he showed that he is an all around great actor and can play any roll. Of course Li Gong did a great job. I think that the action scenes that were in the movie were excellent but the CGI Zhang Yimou likes to use still gets on my nerves. It makes the fights look more fake than real but it wasn't used as much as it was in "House of Flying Daggers".

I read some reviews for this film right before I went out to rent it and found them to basically say this film is mediocre. I was tempted to just forget about this film because of those comments but they didn't really make any good points as to why I shouldn't see it. I still had to see this film mostly because of the amazing and colorful preview. After seeing this movie I understand why it might not have reached some peoples expectations. The problem with Curse of the Golden Flower is the previews definitely advertise the film to have a pretty good amount of action or to be action packed. This film being from the same director of "Hero" and "House of Flying Daggers" I think a lot of action presented evenly throughout the film was expected. Though I understand this problem it was not one that I had with the film. You could say that it relies on its beautiful and I do mean beautiful settings but the story has some life in it as well. This is a great film and very much worth seeing but some people will love it and some will find flaws in it. It depends on how much of your imagination you let run with it.

"The Curse of the Golden Flower" while offering striking scenes of epic proportion akin to any multi-million dollar venture offers little more than conspicuous consumption. There are dramatic scenes illuminated in gold, flowers and such...seemingly like an olympic prelude. This movie lacks sufficient character development, such as Yimou's other ventures such as "the road home," "hero" "house of flying daggers" "raise the red lantern" and "to live." Those movies captivating in both cinematography, character and emotion. It strikes a chord in the soul upon watching these films. However, I was highly disappointed in this venture because the characters were not drawn out. Gong Li's character, Chow Yun's character and such were not really full people that I cared about. Jay Chou's character is probably the most believable, however none of the plot seems to amount to much even with all the shimmering glam and low cut europeanized outfits the women wear. It does not appear to even be the Tang Dynasty, the culturally rich dynasty in Chinese history. The costuming, including the armor looks alien, appearing to be more Victorian era than Tang Dynasty and detracts from the film. Though it was effective in highlighting the extent of corruption, it fell so far short of Zhang Yimou's ability. I felt as if that hour and 45 minutes lay wasted before me in the strange decadence of the film. There is no particular dialoug or scene that sticks out in my conscious and I was not moved by any aspect of this vastly empty film. Maybe I expect to much from such a brilliant filmmaker and writer, but I cannot understand why such a film was even made, why so much money was wasted and why Zhang Yimou or Gong Li, Chow Yun Fat or Jay Chou would attach their names to such a waste of time.

As a fan of Hero and House of the Flying Daggers, I was expecting more of the fantasty style of story telling and action.  While the fantasy aspect from the previous films occured, they did so in a far more real light, and were only used in a very minor way.  But that's to the side.  The meat of this movie is the story of the corrupt royal family, in an almost King Lear or Greek Tragedy form.  The events unfold in a slow, but ultimately very satisfying way, with twists and turns that throw what you thought you knew out the window.  The performances by all involved were amazing, and I was able to loose the fact that Chow Yun-Fat was not his usual charming self, but instead a utterly cruel and tryanical emperor.  While I would like to say this is a movies for fans of Hero and House of Flying Daggers, I can't.  This a different type of movie, but is none the less a very satisfying one.  I highly recomend seeing it.

Note: Chinese with English subtitles (optional feature with audio in English and Mandarin).

`Curse of the Golden Flower' released in `07  is a strange, confusing mixture of genres that leaves one to wonder what was the original intent behind making this film. Is it a period piece, an exotic romance, a tale of political intrigue, an opulent soap opera, or a violent and bloody martial arts epic? Well, it's all of the above and I guess that's ok if the formula works. Unfortunately for the majority of the film it doesn't.

The movie begins slowly with the Emperor and his royal family doing partaking in long sequences of introductions and posturing. The English subtitles are stiff and lacks substance, too bad I don't speak Chinese. The film does gain some momentum midway through but then a lot of what it gains is lost in an endless torrent of blood and death at the end. As for the overall message of the film, I would surmise it's something much like that of `Hero.' The Emperor is always right no matter how wrong he really is.

While `Curse of the Golden Flower' does supply the magnificent visuals we've come to expect from Chinese epics in recent years the film lacks the artistic style and poetic depth of such classics as `Hero' and the romantic, emotional impact of `Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.'

Another area where this film falls short of expectations is the dismal soundtrack that is reminiscent of a never-ending funeral dirge. It's slow, monotonous, boring and pompous. Definitely not something you would listen to on its own.

On a positive note, the cast is excellent with such well known stars as Chow Yun-Fat and Gong Li and lesser known but fine performances by Chou Jay, Liu Ye and the very lovely Li Man as Chan.

If you watch it just for the visuals you won't be disappointed. My rating: 3  Stars.

I really like this movie for its color and its plot.  Being from China, I don't find the plot hard to understand at all.  Perhaps the plot could be odd to a Westerner, especially if its seen with all the ancient Chinese rituals, but I found the story to be very engaging, very absorbing.  And the acting was great.  I was still thinking about the movie the next day.

While it's undeniable that Curse of the Golden Flower is visually stunning throughout, the plot leaves much to be desired. The royal family has many terrible secrets. That's the basic plot. Although the semblance of a full story is attempted, it never really develops entirely, which leaves the viewer with many questions and much confusion when the credits finally roll.

Also, there's not much action although the preview consisted almost entirely of action. So, a misleading preview is another downfall of this film. The problem is that at its core Curse of the Golden Flower is an intimate family portrait of a royal family that is falling apart. But the characters aren't developed enough (or likeable enough) to keep the viewer's attention, or to pull any heartstrings.

The lavish costumes and sets are beautiful to look at, but they start to blend into each other when everything is the same goldish color. The actions scenes are amazing, but too few and they don't come in til after the first hour of the film.

Anyway, most reviewers are right in saying this is a film you want to rent because I don't there's much rewatch value here.

Firstly lets be clear about thing, this is not a martial arts movie  though it has some incredible martial arts scenes that will take your breath away and leave you looking on in stunned wonder.

Also it is a foreign language film, fortunately not dubbed but with subtitles, not everyone's cup of tea but this will not stop you from enjoying ever single second of it, from the opening credits to the blood splattered ending.

The Curse of the Golden Flower is a sumptuous tale about family secrets, revenge, lust, desire, incest, adultery, power, and corruption, all wrapped up in a beautiful but very flawed package that is the Forbidden City of 10th century China.

Never before has one come across such a dysfunctional family as the Tang dynasty, the exquisite but deadly Empress Phoenix, played by the gorgeous Li Gong, the thoroughly amoral Emperor Ping, a glorious Yun Fat Chow in his element, his three sons, the weak Crown Prince Wan (Ye Liu)who has been having an affair with his stepmother, the Empress, Prince Jai, (Jay Chou) brilliant solider, and loyal son to his mother, torn between duty and love, he will make a fateful decision that will herald the beginning of the end for his family.  And last but certainly not least the spoilt and unloved Prince Yu, (Junjie Qin) whose hatred of his family is cunningly disguised by his seemingly placid nature and acceptance of his lowly third son status.

Add to this mix, an Imperial Physician (Dahong Ni) with a wife (Jin Chen) whose connection to the royal household is a closely guarded secret, her daughter the lovely Chan (Man Li) who is is in love with the Crown Prince and you have the ingredients for a tragedy on a scale that can only be imagined.

With breathtaking scenery, the carpet of golden chrysanthemums has to be seen to be believed, fantastic costumes, atmospheric background music, coupled with stunning fight sequences between assassins and royal guards you will be left with your jaw hanging down as you witness the golden warriors go into battle against the Emperor and the twists and turns in a film that is none stop action and intrigue throughout.

The overall acting is without doubt perfection on celluloid, its a shame it didn't win an Oscar but sometimes Hollywood gets it wrong, and boy did they get it wrong this time!

'Curse of the Golden Flower' starts off intriguingly enough, but that's more or less where its allure ends since it never really delivers on its grandiose ambitions, except on a mostly visual basis.

First of all the cinematography is stunning, then again this is to be expected by Zhang Yimou given his already impressive filmography.  His films have this larger than life scope that are simply breathtaking to behold in terms of set designs and choreography, whether it's martial arts or battles and this film is no exception to the rule.  Zhang's ability to coordinate a myriad of events into one seamless scene after another is remarkable, but this time around his directorial blessing is cursed by his inferior script.

'Curse of the Golden Flower's story suffered from lack of character development and mostly unsympathetic participants, then there is the issue of significant plot holes as well.  Some of the fight scenes were incongruous as well as superfluous both in execution as well as relevance, and various characters' motivations were far from explained sufficiently, particularly towards the end.

The first half of the film dragged plot wise and then all of a sudden there was a rush during the final chapter to expose various characters' dark secrets and desires, some that literally came out of nowhere which added almost nothing worthwhile to the overall story.

Aesthetically pleasing to be sure, with amazing locations, beautiful costumes, effective makeup and captivating cinematography, but despite those strong elements as well as decent acting, it really does not work all that well without an equally powerful plot to support their weight.  Chow Yun Fat is a highly capable actor but unfortunately he does not have enough material to truly showcase his talent, as seen in the superior film 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'.  Gong Li was the strongest performer of the cast, but even her effort was not enough to save this film since the script does not fully explain her motivation and as such it made it difficult to relate to her, and the same was true for the rest of the actors.

The real story behind this piece of ancient Chinese history is interesting, but the script does not really reflect it that well, primarily because it assumes too much prior knowledge from the audience, and essentially jumps into the middle of the story with little to no introduction of all the circumstances regarding events and characters.  For a film that lasts nearly two hours there is an awful small amount of plot development and it's not enough to justify its length.

Zhang Yimou wrote the script, but clearly he is a more talented director than writer.  This film's script suffers from some of the same problems as another movie he wrote and directed, 'House of Flying Daggers', although it had a little more cohesive storyline than his latest creation.

I would recommend renting this film to any fan of Zhang's prior work as well as newcomers, but it's not the kind of film worth watching more than once, unless one mostly watches films for their aesthetic value.  For those expecting a captivating and in depth storyline, skip this tragic yet empty tale.

Good look into pre-century Chinese custom and beautiful to look at, but that's about it.  So much over-kill in every way:  manner of dress, emotions, the actors' lines, plot... everything.  Curse of the Golden Flower has nowhere near the elegance and/or grace of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon or Hero.  Rent it.

Allusions to _The Lion in Winter_ while discussing _Curse of the Golden Flower_ are well-earned, because in the beginning there do seem to be some similarities--the current emperor (Chow Yun Fat), relatively late in his years as ruler, has some disagreement when it comes to naming the successor among his three sons.  His wife (Gong Li) of course has her own plans.

But what is the essence of royal family drama if it is NOT the squabbles that go on in regards to succession?  This has been the stuff of Shakespeare and even before, so while some parallels to _The Lion in Winter_ may seem obvious, _Winter_ explores a bit more of the powerful connection and disparity between love and power, while _Curse of the Golden Flower_ seems to dwell mostly on the essence of family secrets themselves.  While the secrets aren't all that much of a surprise (and I tend to think shouldn't be, for the film's focus seems to be out to present the intricacies of secrets among royal family members and the anguish they cause), they do combine to create a web of deceit that this family seems to tread upon each day, knowing of each other's deceit and yet co-existing (to an extent) at the same time...

...until, of course, those secrets come full circle at the Festival of Chrysanthemums, where all will be revealed...

Of course, since this is directed by Yimou Zhang, there are spectacular and thickly casted sequences to be expected, and Zhang does not disappoint.  With this film and _Hero_, Zhang presents the awe and spectacle and the power of the emperial days in a way that _300_ could only put as a backdrop, but the sheer walls of humanity that are used in some of the stunning fight sequences of _Curse of the Golden Flower_ are amazing to behold.  Ancient warfare has finally been dealt with cinematically the way historians have known about it for decades--as an organized force of awesome power.  But Zhang also keeps the awesome visuals to moments even as small as the announcing of the hour in the hallways of the palace, or in sneak attacks on the Emperor's enemies.

The battles and visuals of _Curse of the Golden Flower_ are a wonder to behold, especially in the second hour, but the flow of this movie falls victim to the slower moments of _Hero_, when the storyline circulates too much in one spot in a way that doesn't really forward the story, but muddles itself in a fascination for the distrust the royals hold for each other.  Since this has been a theme for centuries, it might have been more productive to have let that web of secrets tell us something further about humanity, rather than look simply at who might be a little better at this secrets game than others.

Okay, my husband and I are avid Asian culture followers.  The thing that has destroyed me is that this movie only has great eye appeal.  It is clearly overdone and reminds me more of a Chinese Halloween.  We usually watch movies like this for the huge climax.  Where this film built you up for such a climax, one never came. If you base great movies on costumes only or superficiality, then this movie is perfect for you. Instead it had some very nice scenes that drag and drag for no reason, other than it was a nice cinematrography, but did nothing to contribute to the story.  The story was ridiculous and don't understand what audience they were trying to appeal to, because they left nothing for anyone to relate or attach to.  I rarely ever say a film was a bit of a waste of time, but in fact don't ever recall ever sayiing that, but this film was so disppointing.  I like a good story with my movies, this story was just nothing short of lame.

The movie evidently pretends to be a Ran-type awe-inspiring masterpiece, but where Akira Kurosawa'a facade of breathtaking scenery and colorful constumes takes a second place to a compelling message of the film, the Curse of the Golden Flower really has no message at all, just a succession of unrealistic, ahistorical scenes cast in such bright colors as to pain the eye. I think the movie stands a chance as some kind of a surrealist curiosity; for now, I shall assign it to a place of honor in the basement, never to be heard of again.

This is basically a morally depraived horror movie passed off in asian kung-fu garb(age).  I wouldn't watch it again if I was offered $50 to.

OK really you've got to be sceptical about low ratings when you see them on any review forum.  But I have to say, that I don't spend my time writing reviews.  I've purposely made an exception here, to express my disappointments.  Take the lowest star ratings in the series of user reviews here, and that quite well writes up what I could spend 10 minutes trying to rephrase in my own words.

Yes it was beautiful and stunning.  But it was still a sick minded purposeless tragedy.  My spirit is lowered by the waste of talent and money that went into this story.

It reminds me of the hyped shock and awe of the 2nd gulf war.  Over the top glamor, talent, money and effort being put to use in a direction that hurts humanity.

To cut this short, and simplify; this movie is really a negative influence, at a time, in a world that needs all the moral help & heroes it can get.

Zhang Yimou is definitely one of the grandest masters in contemporary cinema when it comes to visuals and scenery that will take your breath away. In "Curse of the Golden Flower" he once again shows us why. It is very beautiful. The scenery, the lighting, the fight choreography, the music, even the actors are beautiful. The direction and editing of course are solid.

Yet there seems to lack substance in the midst of all this beauty. The story is simple with no real twists or turns, the costumes, beautiful as they may be, are not very realistic, and there's a definite lingering feeling that a lot of the scenes in the movie are only there because they can be, eg massive (MASSIVE) armies, HUGE amounts of servants etc.

Basically it follows the current Chinese formula for a grand picture: stunning scenery, beautiful costumes, gorgeous women, and impressive numbers of organized people. There seems to be a competition going on between Zhang Yimou, Feng Xiaogang and the other Chinese directors who can make the most beautiful, most stunning and altogether biggest film.

"Curse of the Golden Flower" will entertain you for a couple of hours, sure, but it's still far, far away from "Hero", which in my humble opinion is not only Zhang Yimous best picture, but one of the best pictures period.

Pros : Absolutely beautiful sets / costumes and superb acting.

Cons : This movie was more of a soap opera than an action martial arts film.  Sure, it had a 30 second 1 on 1 fighting in the beginning and a battle of armies at the end, but I just didn't get enough fighting / martial arts so typical of this genre.

Rarely have I seen a movie as bursting with luminosity and color as Yimou Zhang's "Curse of the Golden Flower," an eye-popping tale of palace intrigue set in late 10th Century China. Li Gong plays the beautiful Empress Phoenix, who is slowly being poisoned by her husband, the Emperor Ping (Yun-Fat Chow), as punishment for the affair she is having with her stepson and heir-to-the-throne, the Crown Prince Xiang. When she discovers what is being done to her, she enlists the aid of one of her own sons (Ye Liu) to help her carry off a carefully orchestrated coup against his father.

"Golden Flower" has just about everything a historic drama done in the grand operatic style needs to be successful: passion, forbidden love, incest, jealousy, betrayal, revenge, family secrets, and, of course, oodles and oodles of blood-soaked battle sequences that pay homage to the richest traditions of the martial arts (picture to yourself an oriental "Lord of the Rings" to get some idea of the scale and scope of these fight scenes). The melodrama does get a bit out-of-hand from time to time, hitting a peak of silliness long about the last half hour or so of the movie. But the film itself is so visually ravishing and gorgeous to look at that we go along with it even when it's not all that easy to take the story it's telling very seriously.

Prime credit for the movie's success goes to cinematographer Xiaoding Zhao, who has wrought various miracles with his lighting and camera, making the rich and shimmering colors literally pop from the screen in unmatched brilliancy and vibrancy. Equally stunning are the production and costume design by Tingxiao Huo and Chung Man Yee, respectively. It is a tribute to the quality of the actors that they are able to stand out so vividly even amidst such peerlessly sumptuous settings.

Small wonder why this is the most expensive and commercially successful Chinese film ever made.

This film is a first  stone or one of the first stones on the road that is leading China to inundating the average, under the average and slightly over the average public of the globalized world with brilliant decorative films that contain little but shine a lot. The setting, the palace, the costumes, all the elements that build the image we see on the screen are marvellous and admirable, even if the falling weapons sound like table forks and if it all looks like an illusionary illusion of beaming gold and silver. The intrigue, the plot, the action is nothing at all except some wide and hefty internal fight in the imperial family that is reduced to a pack of rats in a big pot. They eat one another alive and their mouths are dripping with blood, human blood mind you, more than the mouth of Anne Rice's vampires. So we jump from father killing to mother killing to brother killing to neighbour killing to whatever you may think of killing, and of course the boss will save his skin with a little help from some ninja turtle warriors and from some soft Kung Fu fighters. It is kind of sad to see so much money wasted on such a super production that has no meaning, not even that of a metaphor of the modern world. Luckily our world has changed slightly and you don't need to kill your mother, your father, your brothers and sisters to become president of our modern states, even if at times the competition is tainted with some doping activity trying to boost your votes.

GREAT! The Zhiang Yimou direction (Hero, House of Flying Daggers) and his story script are riveting as this film builds pace from a necessarily slow start - it is dramatic instead of melodramatic, with its endng shots truly disturbing and painful; it has an emotional depth beneath its stunning surface. Gong Li, so often his partner and also hi ex-lover, surely has to be one of the greatest actresses of the past decade -- can you think of a less than compelling performance from her? Red Lantern, 2046, Memoirs of a Geisha, Concubine, Shanghai Triad, even Miami Vice? Or a less than subtle and powerful one from Chow Yun Fat (Crouching Tiger, Anna and the King of Siam)? The sheer beauty of every scene can lead the viever perhaps to discount the power of the acting and the story. It is a study of power and evil. While Gong Li owns the screen, Chow Yun Fat owns the plot. Amid all the costumes and decor, they come alive so vibrantly. There is not a false note in any scene.

What a rich wealth of films China is producing! And along with Gong Li comes Zi Yi Zhang (Hero, Daggers, Crouching Tiger, Geisha,2946) and Maggie Chung. And Zhang Zimou is the master director who brings out their beauty and brilliance.

My advice to anyone coming afresh to all these films is let them work their magic on you and enter into their ambience. The only way they are boring is if you demand the quick hits of the typical US film. Take the Chinese masterpieces on their own terms. Allow yourself to enjoy them.

As others have stated, the sets are very colorful and intricate.  But the CGI of the palace is lacking and the plot is tedious at best.  What little fighting in the movie is ruined by cartoonish ninja-like assassins.  Gong Li is a beauty, but it was tough to sit through this movie.  Definitely not as good as House of Flying Daggers, Hero, or Crouching Tiger.

"Curse of the Golden Flower" is a fantastic film with the most eye-poppingly gorgeous sets I've ever seen and a plot worthy of the Bard himself, yet it somehow falls short of the perfection of Zhang Yimou's previous films, "Hero" and "House of Flying Daggers".  The acting is brilliant; Chow Yun-Fat and Gong Li give the kind of nuanced performances that you seldom see in American films and if you are still raving about "Wild Hogs" or "Night at the Museum" be assured that you will miss almost everything that makes this film great.  The plot revolves around the members of a royal family, a stiff and formal bunch even by imperial dynastic standards.  You see, the emperor is an eccentric fellow, absolutely unshakeable in his belief that all things have their place and each must serve their purpose to a T.  Watching the family interact is uncomfortable to begin with, and as the film progresses we see what lies beneath the layers of this family's veil of propriety.  Believe me, it ain't pretty.  Each member of the family plays their role as they are expected too, but the end result is far from the order that their patriarch craves so much; what eventually comes out of this perfect family is utter and complete chaos. While the story slowly unfolds and builds toward the momentous climaxes, we are treated to the wonderful sights of the imperial palace, which is like a character unto itself in the movie, so beautiful that it even forced mine eyes to veer away from the always-enchanting Gong Li on several occasions.  The first few acts will no doubt bore your average movie-goer looking for the superb action scenes that we've come to expect from these high-profile Chinese period pieces, and that's where this film loses a star.  The film takes so long building up that the feast for the eyes that is the palace almost takes it over.  Besides the lavish sets and extravagant costumes, there isn't much to do but wait for something to happen.  The actors are forced to remain perfectly neutral and formal as their characters command and, while Gong Li can speak volumes with just her eyes, it's not something most folks are going to want to watch for an hour and a half before the ninja attack.  Oh yes, there are ninjas. It's no secret that Zhang Yimou has an eye for exceptional action shots and he upholds this mantle in several scenes as well as a large-scale battle that sees the beautiful palace's surrounding field of golden flowers trampled and replaced with a pile of corpses.  There are some things I'd love to give away in order to illustrate the brilliance of the character development, but I'm afraid it would spoil the ending.  If you look at film as a true art form, are in the mood for a subtle-yet-epic Shakepearian tale, or enjoy the films of Akira Kurosawa, your prayers have been answered;  buy this film.  But if you just saw the commercial on tv and thought everybody'd be kung-fu fighting then give "Curse of the Golden Flower" a pass and have a look at "Hero" instead; a slightly superior film to this one that manages to give you all the action, drama, romance, and visual poetry one can fit into one film.

Yimou Zhang once again produces a work that retains his position as one of the master builders of contemporary cinema. His ability to capture an intricate story historically based in a setting of splendor is up there with the great filmmakers.  CURSE OF THE GOLDEN FLOWER is no exception.

The time of the story is the Tang Dynasty, one of the more corrupt and cruel periods in Chinese history.  Emperor Ping (Chow Yun Fat) has married a princess from the neighboring province, becoming Empress Phoenix (Gong Li) and in addition to becoming stepmother to the Emperor's firs-born son (Ye Liu), she bears him two additional sons (Jay Chou and Junjie Qin). Attending the palace is a doctor (Dahong Nim) and his wife (Jin Chen) who figure significantly in the family's destiny.  Each of these dysfunctional family members has secrets that could destroy an empire. The Empress is clearly the titular head of the kingdom and her wily manipulations and incestuous relationships are controlled only by her doses of a medicine that is supposed to make her insane.  The boils on the body of the ruling family fester until great wars break out and the royal family is revealed to be the strangely bizarre group they are.

The story works (though admittedly it is often difficult to follow) because of a brilliant cast and a pacing from the director that almost matches the glory of the visual production that seems to keep growing on the screen, like a huge garden bearing more color and moods as the story progresses. Yimou Zhang is a visual artist and choreographer but he is also a man with the gift of finding the cores of his characters beneath all the glorious trappings of this films.  Grady Harp, March 07

As he did with Hero and House of Flying Daggers, Yimou Zhang brings us yet another visually stunning film. In CURSE, the story centers around the royal family, and here we find an attempt at Shakespearean drama. The royal family is a mess. The Emperor is poisoning his Consort, the Empress, and she is sleeping with the Crown Prince, the Emperor's son from his first wife - a son who calls the Empress Mother (at least he did in the English translation; I don't know how that would work itself out in Chinese). The Crown Prince, in turn, is sleeping with the daughter of the Imperial Physician, who himself is married to a woman with a mysterious background. It sounds like a great place to start, and perhaps it is, but with all of that suspiciously European Medieval-like court intrigue to be played out, very little happens in the first fifty-five minutes. We see gorgeous costumes, and the inside of a beautiful palace so stunningly colorful that it might give an epileptic a seizure; if the sun were to find its way in just so, it would be the mother of all kaleidoscopes and disco balls. We are inside of said palace for the majority of the film, which may be a problem in itself. Zhang does wonders with open land and panoramic scenes. He did grace us with some in this film, and they were magnificent. Scenes involving would-be assassins using grappling hooks and curved blades were poetically brilliant. But the story, which should start out as a bud and bloom full, chooses instead to shy away from the light. There is resolution, and the threads do play themselves out, but they don't do so in a way that garners intrigue or interest. Others have sung this film's praises, and one must wonder if they are still basking in the afterglow of Hero and House of Flying Daggers. If so, it's understandable. Those were extraordinary films. This serves to prove the axiom that insists beauty is only skin deep. It is true with films as it is with people. There needs to be something below the surface. As this is a review of the DVD, I need to comment on the subtitles and languages. Being hearing impaired, I find this to be important and often overlooked. The DVD offered English as a language, so I selected that - I can hear well enough - and I selected English subtitles - I can't hear *that* well to get by without them. I could, however, hear well enough to know that the spoken word varied greatly from the "subtitled word". It was worthy of a few laughs. At least they offered English as a language. Not all foreign films, even wildly successful ones, do. CURSE get points for that. 2 stars, rounded up to 3.

I note that an earlier reviewer saw the 'making-of' featurette. and it's

a good intro into peeling away the layers of this quasi-Shakespearean melodrama. There's something dramatists like, the theme of the darkness beneath the beauty.

Slow starting, Director Zhang moves faster and faster telling the tale of unfolding faces (in an asian sense) and the complexities of relationships,

veering every so-often in to soap-operatics. Yet with extravagant graphics/ production qualities and a nice pattern of on-and-off action with teary or sneer-y  confrontations and trysts, even the maybe too-dramatic elements work well.

Now, if only a quality version of RAISE THE RED LANTERN would be released, Zhang Yimou's stature as a world-class director would be rightly, finally, established. With his successes this millennium, it might just happen for the man...

The Tang dynasty was the Golden Age period in China, and yet for all the glory there was a lot of internal turmoil. Zhang Yimou is renowned for sumptuous dramas like Raise the Red Lantern, and epics such as Hero and House of Flying Daggers. In Curse of the Golden Flower, we are given an intimate look at the dysfunctional Imperial Family of China, headed by the Emperor [played with consummate skill by Chow Yun Fatt], the Empress Phoenix [Gong Li, as lustrous as always], and his three sons, the Crown Prince [who was borne by an earlier wife], Prince Jai [whose loyalty to his mother is without equal], and young Prince Cheng. Dark secrets and evil machinations dominate throughout the film, and we see the gradual destruction of the Imperial Family due to lies, internal strife and treachery from within the ranks. The acting is good, especially Gong Li's, as she speaks eloquently with a glance or gesture, making her meaning plain without dialogue. The costumes are amazing, simply gorgeous and well-deserving of the Oscar nomination. As for the cinematography, it is lush and beautiful, evoking a sense of a bygone era. A cinematic treat indeed!

Curse of the Golden Flower is a brutal and beautiful look at the inner court of a Chinese Dynasty. When distrust and ill-intent creep in, the stage is set for a powerful and gripping masterpiece.

Anyone familiar with past works of Zhang Yimou knows they are in for a visual masterpiece. Curse is no exception. The use of color that Yimou is so well known for is apparent throughtout with vibrant and awe inspiring locals, backdrops, and costumes. Truely one of his greatest visual works.

The story is not quite as convoluted and twisting as those of Yimou's past works (Hero, House of Flying Daggers) and lays itself out relatively early. That isn't to say it doesn't have its share of twists. It is more about the personification of what the knowledge of the situation does to the members of the royal family. Why they act as they do. And how they plan to resolve everything, each in their own way. An amazing work of characterization capped off with solid performances from the main cast of characters.

Chow Yun Fat plays the Emperor to perfection. He is cold and calculating, while remaining a sense of majesty and humanity despite some of his actions. The three princes are portrayed wonderfully by some very competent actors. Especially the roles of Prince Jai and Crown Prince Wan. As the movie progresses the roles of the princes begin to become far more than you could ever imagine and family lines are drawn as sides are taken.

But out of all the wonderful astetics and performances, nothing outshines Gong Li. Her portrayal of the Empress is absolutely breathtaking. Gong Li is known more for her dramatic roles than those she has in action movies and I was worried initially, but she really doesn't take part in any of the action and her full abilities as a dramatic actress are on display to be seen. Harnessing various emotions ranging from pain, suffering, loss, heartache, and anger, Gong Li crafts a character that is to be admired and adored by all. This truely is one of her greatest works ever.

Overall, Curse of the Golden Flower is another amazing movie by Zhang Yimou. The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is I personally expected more story. While the story that is here is wonderful and really draws you in, I think maybe I may just be jaded by Yimou's other masterpieces of the last few years. Still, it should be no reason to prevent anyone from seeing this movie. I can't recommend it enough.
