The success of foreign martial arts films has given rise to beautifully executed movies such as "Hero" and "House of Flying Daggers". Now, "Curse of the Golden Flower" adds it's weight to the ranks, and upholds this particular style of film perfectly.

Due to the style of the film, and the general language barrier (as a language, Chinese and Japanese can sometimes be difficult to translate into English), the plot can get a little confusing at times, but it eventually irons itself out later on. The main gist of the plot is that the Empress of China has discovered that her husband, the Emperor, has been slowly poisoning her with a type of fungi that will cause her to lose all mental capacity if it is taken in small doses over a period of a few months. Upon learning this, she decides to stage a coupe with her most trusted son in an attempt to overthrow the Emperor. There are several side plots, but they mostly serve to create character depth.

As expected, this film is breathtakingly beautiful, from it's set and costumes, to the artistic cinematography. It was nominated at the 2007 Academy Awards for costume design, and it was well deserving of the nomination. Because it is a foreign film, it is of course subtitled, but the viewer also has an option to change the subtitles to English dubbing instead. However, I always prefer to use the subtitles because I feel that there is something lost when altering the voice inflection with someone speaking English who is *not* the original actor. There isn't much dialogue to begin with. The film makes liberal use of non-verbal looks, gestures, and body language to get it's point across, which lends itself to the strength of the actors to be able to create this intricate story with limited dialogue.

The vibrant color pallete is striking, and is well worth viewing the movie, even if you end up not liking it. I would recommend this film to any who enjoy foreign films.

"Gold and jade on the outside, rot and decay on the inside". This is the old Chinese proverb director Zhang Yimou quoted when attempting to describe the overall theme of this movie...and well, I could not agree with him more! While Curse of the Golden Flower does look beautiful and lavish on the outside with its flashy exterior, at its core it is almost devoid of just about everything else.

Curse of the Golden Flower centers around an imperial family that eventually falls apart. As of this writing, this is the most expensive movie ever made in China and it definitely shows. Everything from the re-imagination of the Forbidden City to the interior of the royal palace illustrates the amount of care and precarious work emphasized on detail. Some of it is not all great, especially those bizarre glowing pillars. The costumes themselves looked remarkably funny, especially since the actors were always struggling to keep such weight on them while appearing awkwardly serious in their performances.

The movie delves into the personalities of the characters and each of their own distinct motives. However, it still does little or nothing to add or enrich the story, which frequently borders on being predictable on more than one occasion while at times not even driving any kind of story at all. It uses virtually every single dysfunctional royal family clich in the book. There is no real sense of urgency as to what's happening because nothing is truly developed. By the time the so-called "hidden family secrets" are finally revealed, it all isn't as cracked up as it was supposed to be. And somehow were expected to be shocked or surprised?

As for the starring roles, Chow Yun Fat does nothing convincing as a senile emperor except to stroke his beard while dishing out proverbs. Gong Li's version of drama is to cry and tremble in front of the camera while being careful with her breasts falling out. Jay Chou and Liu Ye as the emperor's sons don't do anything noteworthy. The dialogue in this movie is particularly boring if you know Mandarin, and everything is just overacted and taken too seriously than what it should be. Curse of the Golden Flower also contains some of the most laughable scenes in Chinese cinema history, a few of which made purely for shock factor. This is about a dysfunctional family, yet why should we care?

This movie drew inspiration from Thunderstorm, written by Cao Yu. Unfortunately, Zhang Yimou decided to mutilate and transform this wonderful classic story into a bloated big-budget carnival extravaganza, complete with a bombardment of colors, showy breasts, and also found the time to include some martial arts and epic army CGI action while he was at it. He even hired an all-star cast, although their roles did not require any of them to do much with talent except to utilize their celebrity status in order to sell the film. And all this for what? For the sake of just generating box office numbers?

It seems as though Zhang Yimou felt like he couldn't win an Academy Award when he reverted back to his old style with Riding Alone For Thousands of Miles, so he comes back to doing Hollywood stuff like this. If Chen Kaige's The Promise was the worst original Chinese movie ever made, then Curse of the Golden Flower has got to be the worst Chinese adaptation ever made. As a lesson to be learned, Zhang should have paid close attention to those very words that inspired him to make this film in the first place: "Gold and jade on the outside, rot and decay on the inside". It ended up describing this movie all too perfectly.

Although a few of the other review allude to the weak plot, I am surprised no one has noticed that the plot of this film has more in common with an episode of "Dynasty" with Chow Yun Fat in the "Blark Carrington" role and Gong Li as "Alexis Colby" - and it seems that every hack-kneed soap opera plot devise is used - the upstairs/downstair romance, the wide who resents her over baring husband and has an affair with her much sexier step-son, the first wife thought to be dead who shows as the star witness of the nurder trial (oops!, that last one was from "Dynasty").  The film is beautiful to look at but I became very "aware" of how much CGI effects were used to create the thousands of soliders.

Then of course the plot borrows heavily from Shakespeare's "Hamlet" and "Macbeth" as well...

I saw Curse of the Golden Flower at the movie and it was great. The story is very entertaining, the costumes are well done and the sets have lots of color, makes you feel like your in 10 century China. Gong Li is gorgeous playing the role of the empress. If you like martial arts films, I highly recommend you get this movie.

It seems as if Zhang Yimou has exchanged his former style and art for flashy, hollywood type battles and drama.  Raise the Red Lantern was nothing less than a marvelous film that is artistic yet appeals to the average viewer.  For this movie, it seems as if he finished watching the Siege at Helm's Deep in LOTR and decided he wanted to make one that is in Chinese.  Poorly, anyway.

The plot isn't incomprehensible but the usage of the word plot is a stretch.  It seems as if all the cast members, however poorly cast, are just plotting for plotting sake.  You don't feel for any of the characters, because they're never developed beyond the fact that everyone is unhappy and suffering.  It's a cynical movie.  All the women are running around wearing masking tape on their breasts so they get pushed up to shoulder level.  It was distracting and a bit disturbing.  What better way to promote a mediocre movie than exposed cleavage right?

Also, it seems as if everyone is living in a giant fun house or something.  Can we say Batman and Robin?  Bright colors like a flashy red and does not make for an epic.  The tone of the movie is so dark and cynical yet the colors are so bright....  The direction is eye rollingly tedious.  Throughout the entire movie, he Zhang has to do sweeping camera pans and slow motion shots of battles that's probably been done in Hollywood 6 years ago and better as well.  Hair becoming disarrayed in slow motion, characters over dramatically taking their robes off before a fight...!  Please stop trying to make a Hollywood movie, Zhang!

Jay Chow was very poorly cast.  Chow Yun Fat's mandarin is the epitome of HONG KONG style mandarin.  Gong Li's talents are just wasted portratying a one dimensional character.  Everything is just overly dramatic to the point of nausea.  Everyone is backstabbing each other for no real apparent reason, that's basically the 'plot'.  This might be all right if they weren't a bunch of wooden one dimensional characters.

If you want to watch a good Zhang Yimou movie and a great one in general, watch Raise the Red Lantern.  Now that is truly epic and leaves a very lasting impression.  Not to mention it has a great soundtrack.

This is a beautiful film.  The costumes and cinematography are clearly Oscar quality and the best I have seen in a very long time.  The sub-titles can be a little tiresome because they distract from the visual beauty of the film, but a great deal of the action is visual and implied through body language.  The plot is very complicated and includes incest, betrayal, secrets, and the drive for power. There are enough twists and turns to keep your interest and even a few surprises.  There are some martial arts scenes which I felt were a little overdone but there weren't enough to spoil the film.  The final scenes in the Forbidden City are truly spectacular and show great cinematography.

The movie is essentially a Greek Tragedy with the outcome one expects from a Greek  Tragedy.  One is reminded of Agamemnon, Clytemnestra, and Orestes as the royal family self-destructs over jealousy, power, and revenge.  In the end the King is left with nothing but his power -- a hollow victory.

The costumes are truly spectacular, the screen play well done, the cinematography outstanding, and the acting of the highest quality.  I gave the film four stars because I felt much of the martial arts could have been eliminated and didn't add a great deal to the film.  Nevertheless this is an excellent film and well worth watching.
